titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Mr: Ewing called on me this morning— I went with him and attended public worship at a Quaker meeting— The first that I ever attended— There were four Speakers; two men, and two women— I paid a visit before dinner to Mr: Meredith. Dined at Mr: Hopkinson’s— With Miss M’Pherson, Mr: Condy— Mr: Pierson, and Mr: Ewing— In the Evening I called at Dr: Rush’s; and at Mr: Gilman’s lodgings— The Dr: was abroad. Mr: Gilman, was confined by his lameness to his chamber— On coming home in the Evening, I found the child very unwell— And after going to bed, I was roused from it, and obliged to send for Dr: Rush to him— The Dr: sent his son— We were up with the child untill past two in the morning.

2. The Child continued so ill this day that we concluded to postpone our departure for New-York untill to-morrow— I called early at the Stage-Office, and had the transfer of our seats made, upon the books— Dr: Rush called to see the child both in the morning and Evening— I walked alone before dinner, and with the Ladies early in the Evening— Great part of the day I suffered severely with the tooth-ache; and not less with the tedious languor of absolute idleness.

3. At eight this morning we left Philadelphia in the Diligence Stage— Dined at Trenton about 1. and reached the end of the days journey at Brunswick about 8 in the Evening.— The face of the Country was unusually beautiful. The Spring far advanced— The orchards all in blossom— But the roads were excessively dusty— We had also some unpleasant companions on the road. Just at the entrance of Brunswick, I stop’d at the house of Mr: Henry Guest, an old man 81 years of age, as I had promised in answer to a letter I had received from him containing a request to that effect— He gave me a cane to take with me as a present from him to my father; and three copies of a pamphlet published by himself. He had some conversation with me on political subjects, and invited me to lodge in his house, which however I declined, having too large a family with me to be accommodated with comfort either to them or to him.

4. Between 4 and 5. this morning we left Brunswick in the Stage, and reached Paulus-Hoek about 11— We breakfasted on the way at Elizabeth-Town. Our most troublesome fellow-traveller of yesterday, took offence at something which happened last Evening, and came on with the Mail-Stage— The remainder of the journey was the more agreeable for his absence— We had an unusually short and easy passage at the ferry— On landing in New-York we went to Mrs: Anthony’s house, where we had lodged on our passage through New-York last fall; but we found the house shut up— With the marks of a recent fire, which we were told had been there— We were informed that she was no longer in business, and had probably left the City. We then came to Mrs: Bradish’s at N. 1. Broadway, where we obtained a couple of chambers in the garret— The house is in other respects a very good one— I immediately went down to Crane-wharf and
engaged a passage to Providence, in the Providence Packet Captain Curry, to sail to-morrow morning at 11. O’Clock— After dinner we went with Mrs: Bradish and her daughter, and Mr: John Morton, who is one of our fellow lodgers, to see a panorama, of moveable figures, representing a view of a Street and Square in a City— On returning we went into Trinity Church and saw the Tablet in honour of Genl: Hamilton, and also the Monument in the Church-Yard— I afterwards went to look after my nephew John A. Smith, and met him in the Street. He returned with me, and walk’d with the Ladies on the Battery— After which I called on Mr: King, and sat a couple of hours in conversation with him.— I met Mr: Verplanck this morning in the Street.

5. We were prevented from sailing this day by a very violent Storm from the South-East— It also confined us the greatest part of the day to the house— I went down to the Packet however this morning to inquire whether she would go; and was afterwards out again— John Smith was with us this Evening; Mr: King also called upon me, and pass’d two or three hours with me— I find scarcely any disagreement between his opinions and my own, upon the principal political topics of this time.

6. The weather having become fair and fine we embarked this morning on board the Packet Providence, Captain Curry— Mr: Morton, Mr: Ogden, two of the boarders at Mrs: Bradish’s, and John Smith accompanied us to the wharf— On my way there I met Mr: M’Cormick who was going to visit us— At precisely 11. O’Clock the Gentlemen took leave of us and we sailed— We had a fair and light breeze the whole day, and before the close of the Evening had performed half our passage— Among our fellow passengers are a Mr: and Mrs: Hamilton, and Messrs: Oliver and Goddard of Boston.

7. The wind continued fair and light through the night and all the morning; on rising between 4 and 5. O’Clock I found the vessel immediately opposite the East end of Fisher’s island— From that time untill we came within two miles of Newport, we had a very heavy swell of the Sea, and going with a very light breeze before the wind, almost all the passengers unused to the sea were very sick— At 11. O’Clock we reached Newport Harbour, after a passage of exactly 24 hours— Mr: and Mrs: Hamilton landed at Newport, which several others of the passengers likewise intended, with the view to proceed from thence, immediately by land to Boston— But the breeze promising a short passage to Providence, they concluded finally to remain on board— The weather however soon changed— We had a violent squall of wind and rain; a flat calm and a head-wind, all in quick succession— It was about 5 in the afternoon when we landed at Providence— Mr: Oliver and several others of the passengers immediately took a carriage, and went half way to Boston this Evening— My family together with Mr: Jones, one other of the passengers concluded to remain here for the night— Judge Barnes called in the course of the Evening to see me.

8. We left Providence about 9. O’Clock this Morning, in two Stages; which went to the Half way house in Walpole— There we dined, and proceeded in one Carriage the remainder of the way. At 5. in the afternoon we terminated safely our journey and arrived at our own house at the corner of Nassau-Street at the bottom of the Mall.— We found the house had been made ready for our reception— I went to Mr: Quincy’s; and delivered the letters from Mr: Morton— Pass’d a couple of hours there, and on my return found Dr: Welsh, and Mr: W. S. Shaw at my house— Mr: Shaw spent the Evening with us

9. I intended to have gone this day with Mrs: Adams to Quincy, but was detained by meeting many of my friends, and by a slight indisposition. Mr: Hall called and sat with me an hour— I called on Shaw—at my Office; and at the Offices in State-Street— Dined with Mr: Allen the Sheriff, in company with a number of Gentlemen— After dinner I called at the Governor’s; but he was not at home— Mr: Stedman and Mr: Degrand spent the Evening with us.

10. After calling on Mr: Shaw, and at the Banks, from which I brought home my trunks, I went with my wife and child Charles to my father’s at Quincy— I then went and brought John from Mr: Cranch’s— We dined at my father’s and also pass’d the afternoon there— In the Evening we returned to Boston— I called on Chief-Justice Parsons, and had some conversation with him on political subjects— I found him as I expected totally devoted to the British Policy, and avowing the opinion that the British have a right to take their seamen from our ships—have a right to interdict our trade with her Enemies, other than the peace trade— And a right by way of retaliation to cut off our trade with her Enemies altogether— He also thinks the people of this Country corrupted, already in a state of voluntary subjugation to France, and ready to join an Army of Bonaparte if he should send one here, to subdue themselves— The only protection of our Liberties, he thinks is the British Navy.

11. The Election for members of the House of Representatives in the town of Boston was this day held, and thirty-one members were chosen— I was down in State-Street this forenoon, and settled an Account with Mr: Quincy.— In the Evening I went, notwithstanding the Storm, to the Club, at Judge Davis’s— It was pretty well attended— Mr: Hall, & Mr: Dexter called upon me this morning.

12. I have been intending to go to Cambridge every day this week, but have been prevented by the foulness of the weather, and this day by being very unwell; but I wrote and sent to the President notice that I would attend to-morrow, and deliver a Lecture in the morning, and preside at the declamation at 2. but this evening I found myself so unwell, that I was obliged to send for Dr: Welsh; and was entirely incapable of any useful employment.

div.p: 13. I had an indifferent Night, and found myself this morning very ill— But having engaged to go to Cambridge, I was determined at all hazards to accomplish that object, and sent for a Carriage to take me there— Dr: Welsh went with me. We called at President Webber’s, whom I informed that I must return immediately after the Lecture, and could not stay to the declamation— I left Dr: Welsh with the President and went to Dr: Waterhouse’s— He was at the Library, and the time for the commencement of my lecture had elapsed a quarter of an hour— I immediately went over, found the freshmen in the Library, and delivered my 27th: Lecture. I then went to Dr: Holmes’s— Settled Rapine’s account with him. Call’d at Dr: Waterhouse’s and at the President’s for Dr: Welsh— Found him at the President’s— Returning home I left at Mr: Jonn: L. Austin’s an apology for not dining with him this day according to an invitation received from him two days since— Crossing West-Boston Bridge, I met Captain Mackay the Treasurer of that Corporation, who asked me to call at his house, which I did, and settled accounts with him— I left Dr: Welsh at his house, and reached home myself, between 12 and 1. O’Clock— Pass’d the remainder of the day in my chamber, in great pain, and some fever— Mr: Shaw called upon us in the Evening— Just before bed-time I found myself much relieved.

14. This day I was very much recovered; but was confined at home all the morning by the badness of the weather— We received our baggage that came by water from Washington— Our family remains still very much unsettled— My brother came to Boston this afternoon with Charlotte Welsh, and I returned with him this Evening to my father’s house at Quincy— It was late when we left town; and about 9 at Night when we arrived. I have still been unable this day to do any of my work, but I wrote to Mr: Boyd.

15. Heard Mr: Guild, a young man settled at Milton in the Parish, which Mr: M’Kean lately left— I attended him both parts of the day— In the afternoon I called at Mr: Cranch’s and pass’d an hour— Evening at my father’s. The weather continuing bad none of the Gentlemen of the neighbourhood were there:

16. Returned to Boston this morning in the Stage, which was crowded— Mr: Hall called upon me with Mr: Stocker & Mr: Caton, who wished to know what the prospect was of their obtaining permission to export fish during the summer— Several Ladies called upon Mrs: Adams— I was employed the whole day, in arranging accounts, and wrote nothing for my Lecture— Called however this afternoon, with my boy John, for half an hour at Mr: S. A. Otis’s— Mr: W. Foster, my neighbour called also upon me. Mrs: Adams was very sick this Evening, and the children both unwell.

17. Another day spent almost entirely without writing— I read however a large part of the day— I am exceedingly pressed for want of Time, and resume the thread of my course of Lectures with great difficulty— Governor Sullivan paid me this morning a visit.— Dr: Welsh and his family and Mr: De Grand were here in the Evening— My brother and his wife & daughter, were in from Quincy— Mrs: Adams still continues somewhat unwell.

18. After writing some part of the morning, I went to the old South Church and attended the ordination of Mr: Joshua Huntington as the Colleague of Dr: Eckley— I found Dr: Morse preaching the Sermon— Dr: Dwight the President of New-Haven College where the young Gentleman was educated had been expected; but was arrested on his way by ill health— The Church was crowded, and I took a stand in one of the aisles; but the Committee of the Church soon sent and provided me with a seat, and afterwards gave me an invitation to the public dinner— I accordingly attended it— The dinner was agreeable, but Dr: Osgood of Medford attacked me in a rude and indecent manner on the subject of my letter to Mr: Otis— I told him that in consideration of his age, I should only remark that he had one lesson yet to learn, of which I recommended to him the study as specially necessary— And that was Christian Charity. After dinner I called for an hour at my Office, and spent the Evening with the Ladies at a large party at Mr: S. Dexter’s.

19. According to Dr: Welsh’s recommendation, I confined myself all this day at home— And wrote with great assiduity upon a difficult and most tedious part of my course— In the Evening I walk’d in the Mall, and had much conversation upon political subjects with judge Davis whom I met there— I find him as usual moderate and candid, but like all my other former friends with one or two exceptions, sided against me.

20. Spent the whole day again at home, in close application to the continuance of my lectures. Mr: J. Gardner called upon me this Evening, and I walked a couple of hours with him in the Mall— He is still my undeviating friend— I had much conversation with him on political topics, and find him as I ever did, rational and just— He first informed me that this morning Mr: Emerson was very suddenly seized with a violent haemorrhage from the lungs, and is now dangerously ill.

21. I proceed upon my lectures with a difficulty beyond any thing I have ever experienced before— A difficulty which together with the others which meet and await me call for the exercise of fortitude; the virtue of Adversity— I was for a short time before dinner, walking and at the Insurance Office— The remainder of the day at home writing— Evening in the Mall, walking with Dr: Jackson, whom I met there— I returned Mr: W. Foster’s visit, but did not see him.

22. Heard Mr: Alden this morning, and Mr: Buckminster in the afternoon— It is feared that Mr: Emerson will never again be able to resume his functions— I took John with me in the afternoon— Remainder of the day at home, and wrote part of my lecture—

23. I called this day at Mr: Shaw’s Office, to enquire about his going to Atkinson, to bring home my son George— He told me he should go to-morrow morning; and return on Wednesday or Thursday— In the Evening I called at Mr: Emerson’s, to enquire how he was— I did not see him, but he has been the whole day better than yesterday. Evening at Dr: Welsh’s—where were the Ladies; and Mr: S. A. Otis and Mr: W. Smith with their families— Mr: Isaac Smith was also there— Mr: J. S. Greene this morning came and requested of me a letter to the Secretary at War recommending him for a Captain’s Commission in the troops now levying; which I gave him— He informed me that several of the Commissions had already been received.

24. Mr: Ripley called on us this morning— My father came into Town, and at 11. O’Clock I attended with him the meeting of the Academy— It was for the annual Election of the Officers— There were twenty-five members present— The Officers were all rechosen, excepting the recording Secretary, Judge Davis, and the Treasurer, Mr: James Freeman— Mr: Emerson was chosen instead of the former, and Mr: D. A. Tyng instead of the latter. Several communications were read—in particular from Mr: Bowditch, respecting the late Comet, and the total Eclipse of 16. June 1806.— A motion for holding all the meetings in future at Boston was considered, but postponed without taking any question upon it. About 2. O’Clock the meeting was dissolved;— My father—President Webber—Professor’s Ware, Willard and Farrar, Dr: Waterhouse, Mr: Hedge, Mr: Mellen, Mr: Gannett, Dr: Holmes and Dr: Morse, and Judge Davis, dined with us.— They remained but a
short time after dinner— I pass’d the Evening at the Athenaeum, reading over newspapers and periodical journals.

25. Annual Election day— Rained almost the whole day— The two Branches of the General Court met, and a majority of both being federal Mr: Otis was chosen President of the Senate, and Mr: Bigelow Speaker of the house— The Election Sermon was preached at the Brattle-Street meeting house, by Mr: Allen of Pittsfield— I attended and heard him— Dined afterwards at the Governor’s; with a company of about twenty-five persons— The members of the Council who are going out The late President of the Senate Mr: Dana, and the present President Mr: Otis—The Speaker—The Adjutant General Donnison; and the Quarter Master General Davis— The two houses had adjourned to 5 O’Clock— And the rest of the Company soon after dispers’d— In the Evening I attended the Club at Dr: Dexter’s— Mr: Peck who has just returned from Europe, Mr Gray, Dr: Howard and Dr: Kirkland were there.

26. I pass’d the day at home, with sufficient assiduity, but with very little success, writing upon my lecture— My Son George reached home just before dinner— Mr: Shaw brought him; and they were sometime detained by an accident which befell their Chaise, and from which they luckily made their escape— I was in the Evening at the Athenaeum where I saw Mr: Shaw.

27. Mr: Shaw called upon me this morning, with General Whiting, and a Mr: Atherton who is solliciting a Commission in the new army. Mr: Hall afterwards called, and brought me a pamphlet containing Lord Erskine’s Speech in the English house of Peers, on the 8th: of March, upon the Orders of Council of 11. Novr:— I pass’d the whole day at home, untill the Evening when I walked in the Mall, and afterwards went to the Athenaeum.
28. Pass’d the day in my chamber, closely engaged upon my business, untill my brother came in for me from Quincy— I went out with him to my father’s, and took my son George with me.

29. Heard Mr: Charles Lowell of Boston, who dined with us at my father’s. His Sermon in the afternoon was upon evil-speaking, and a very good one— Mr: Greenleaf and his son, and Captain Beale passed the Evening with us— My mother is confined to her chamber.

30. Return’d to Boston this morning with George, in the Stage— My brother and his wife also came into town this day, & dined with us— Mr: T. Greenleaf junr: dined here— Mr: Everett called after dinner; and Mr: Shaw in the Evening. I pass’d the greater part of the afternoon at the Athenaeum, where I met Mr: Story, and Judge Davis.— I called to see Mr: Gilman.

31. I took my children this morning to School— George to Mr: Webb, and Mr: M’Kean, where he is to go alternately, at the two South Schools—and John to Mrs: M’Clench— But he would not stay there either in the morning or afternoon— Mr: Gilman, and Mr: Gallison were here in the morning— Mr: Charles Foster, and Mr: Degrand in the Evening— I was at the Offices about an hour before dinner, and pass’d the remainder of the day, in my chamber, writing at my lecture.

div.p: Day— The first week of this month we were upon our Journey— Since that time I have delivered one Lecture at Cambridge, the week before the vacation commenced.— At home I usually rise about 7. O’Clock— And excepting half an hour at breakfast, and perhaps an hour at dinner, pass the rest of the day, untill the dusk of Evening in my chamber, reading & writing, on my lectures— I then walk an hour in the Mall, when the weather permits— This has seldom been the case since my return. I have twice been out, and spent the Sunday at Quincy; and have been several days engaged on various occasions, which occur at this period of the year.— My principal object at present is the composition of my lectures, which gives me great anxiety, and upon which the further I proceed the more I am dissatisfied with myself.
